content: I’ve also read about the positive effect of smiling on mood that @RandyMudge mentions. I’m reading a book Thinking, Fast and Slow and it’s fascinating, and surprising, to learn how our facial expressions can affect our thinking. While I don’t think for one minute that smiling can cure depression, I think it can help lift us. In those moments, we can see a light in the darkness that can be comforting and energising. I agree with Randy’s suggestion of walking in nature — it’s an under-used treatment for depression. I haven’t tried Randy’s blade of grass trick (the thought alone made me smile), but walking in nature with trees, flowers, birds and insects, can help over time. For me, there’s nothing that triggers a smile more genuinely than hearing a blackbird sing — no mask, just pure delight. When I hear birdsong, I feel hope. Re-connecting with nature holds the key, I think, to a more meaningful life where we aren’t constantly judging ourselves against a societal yardstick where career status, financial wealth, beauty and selfie ‘likes’ seem to carry more value than what kind of a person we are.
